utterances: Voted today two to one to continue the investigation.
It's stuck in the courts in Florida.
Nothing is getting done there, and they should do something about it.

This is really a stretch here, but if the Democrats, if the Democratic Congress votes to override the sanctioning of this vote and the election is declared - the seat is declared vacant, you're going to have such an uproar, such an anger coming out from both sides in the House that will make the 2000 election look like kids playing in a sandbox.
The emotions are very raw now between the parties.
We see it in Iraq, we see it in basically every issue.
And if the Republicans get these elections taken away from them, as some Republicans fear could happen, you will really see all hell break loose.
So is there likely to be a recount?
Is there likely to be a second election?
What's going to happen?
My gut tells me that they'll say that things went wrong, that things should have been taking - should have been clearer.
That the ballot - we've heard this before - the ballots should have been better designed.
But, ultimately, I think that they're not going to reverse it.
Although there is some precedent in 1984 in Indiana.
There was a victory, a very close race where the Republican secretary of state and the Republican apparatus in Indiana gave the Republicans the victory.
The Democratic House voted to unseat that and gave it to the Democrats.
And again, as we say, all hell broke loose.
And that was one of the reasons cited by the Republicans when they were elected to the majority in 1994 that it was abuse of power, the Democrats were abusing their power.
And we'll see what happens here.
Political junkie Ken Rudin, who writes a column by that name on Web site.
You can read it at npr.org.
And we'll take more of your calls when we come back.
Email is talk@npr.org.

I do also have to thank our callers, bloggers and emailers for reminding me that I mistakenly omitted a word in our promo about tomorrow's show about Turkey, which is of course the sole secular democracy in the Muslim Middle East.
There is another one nearby, which I neglected to say that.
But thank you for pointing that out.
That's tomorrow's show on TALK OF THE NATION.
And you're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Here is an email we have from Vince in Savannah, Georgia.
President Bush made three recess appointments while Congress was adjourned for the Easter break.

Given that such appointments are intended to allow vacancies to be filled rather than wait for an extended period for Congress to reconvene, President Bush's appointment of individuals who would never have gotten congressional approval seems to be a clear abuse of power.
Why does no one challenge the legality of these backdoor appointments?
Well, I mean, the president has the absolute right to do that.
We saw that with Bolton at the U.N.
It was a recess appointment knowing that the Senate would never…
The committee.
He probably would have gotten approved in the Senate.
That's true.
But the committee wouldn't.
That's exactly right.
But look, the Democrats hooting and hollering, and both parties have done this.
Is it an abuse of power?
No, because they have the power to do it.
Does it make for good relations between the two parties, between two branches of government?
Absolutely not.
Okay.
Let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
And this is - oh, excuse me, I hit the wrong button - John.
John's with us from Tucson, Arizona.
Hi.
Listen, I wanted to make a comment about the speaker's comments about non-binding resolutions that are being passed.
You know, I just don't think it's right to categorize these things as somehow mysterious.
These are clearly consensus-building, you know, kinds of measures that are being taken.
It's awfully hard to build a consensus where there's so much political fear about the fallout from any measures that are undertaken about the war.
So I think there are probably lots of viewers like me who feel that these are consensus-building measures and they are important for that very reason.
Ken Rudin?
The caller is absolutely right, but there's also a constituency in the Democratic Party which is angry, which wants U.S.
troops out yesterday, and they feel that non-binding language is just a continuation of the same.
Well, I don't know.
You know, I'm the father of a serving Marine who just returned from Iraq and I'm willing to take any measures that will get us out of there.
Thanks very much for the call, John.
Okay.
Thank you.
Well, perhaps.
Although again, when Steny Hoyer said that they're going to send this back to the president, perhaps that money will stay there.
They're talking about adding a minimum wage language to it as well.
The Democrats obviously need to get something out of it to go home to their constituents and say, look, this is the best we got.
And so I would think that the Katrina stuff, which is really not pork.
I mean, you know, there are two separate things here.
There is pork and there's also much needed legislation to finance the ravaged areas in the Gulf Coast.
But perhaps Katrina money and perhaps the language on minimum wage will remain intact in the next go-around.
Let's get Barbara on the line.
Barbara with us from Paradise, California.
Yes.
Hello there.
Hi.
I've been very upset about nobody discussing public financing for our elections.
I think that so much could be saved if we could get - we could discuss and it could be a real discussion on public financing.
And is this anywhere in Congress?
Is anybody discussing this, Ken Rudin?
Well, look at the advocates of public finance.
I mean John McCain was the author of the McCain-Feingold bill that called for public, you know, financing of campaigns.
Hillary Clinton has long been an advocate of public funding.

And yet, because it's so - I'm not making excuses - but because it's so expensive, because the other guy is spending so much more money, both McCain, both Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama have all (unintelligible) public funds, and they're going to raise and spend as much money as possible.
It's an ugly cycle, but it…
It is ugly.
I think it makes America look like we're buying our candidates and we're buying our president, we're buying our senators.
I think this looks bad to the rest of the world, and it's certainly sounds bad to the voters.

I mean, you know, you hear the announcer saying on radio, well, this candidate has $15 million or this one has $14 million instead of really saying what this candidate has accomplished or what they are really about.
They talk about the money too much.
I hear this all the time.
It is very, very valid.
Basically, we're talking about as if that would determine who would be the best candidate.
Now I will say that you cannot become - you will not be elected president if you're not raising enough money to be competitive.
But for that to be the benchmark, I agree, that's a wrong way to judge candidates.
Barbara, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you very much.
And Ken Rudin, we'll see you again next Wednesday for another edition of the Political Junkie.
Thank you, Neal.
And Ken Rudin is also NPR's political editor.
Again, if you want to read his column, you can go to npr.org.
It's titled the Political Junkie.
This is TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
Amelia Meath and Nick Sanborn each spent time in bands that never made it big.
When the two of them joined up to create Sylvan Esso, everything changed.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""COFFEE"")
(Singing) Get up, get down, get up, get down, feel the general attention and stop, see the mix won't work.
They started filling up high-profile music venues.
They became famous internationally, and almost immediately, they started to feel pressure to make magic a second time.
So three years after their debut album, Sylvan Esso has a sophomore record.
The name gives you some insight into how they felt making it.
The album is called ""What Now.
The reason we named it ""What Now"" was that we realized that we had just grown up a lot since the last record had happened.
And I think the biggest lesson we kept coming back to, the biggest kind of growing up lesson, was this realization that nothing is ever over and that, you know, no great success is going to save you.
You know, no love is going to make you a better person really.
Or whole.
Yeah, and on the flip side, that no defeat is ever the end.
It's funny because I was thinking that the title could be either anticipatory, like, oh, what now, what next, or it could be, like, exasperated, oh, what now.
Exactly.
And you're saying that's both (laughter).
Yeah, that's why we kept it without punctuation.
It was probably the phrase I woke up with in the middle of the night in my head the most in the year that we made the record, which was last year.
Which was 2016.
Yeah.
I mean - which is a year for kind of our species to be shouting that at themselves all the time.
But it was also just personally and professionally - it just took over every aspect of, I think, both of our lives, that one idea.
Probably the track on this record that is the most explicit about its point of view is ""Radio.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""RADIO"")
